usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
inertia: User should feel moderate mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip (about 3 cm Ø)
interactionDeduction: The user will grasp the short wooden handle with a single-handed power grip, fingers and thumb fully wrapping a roughly 3 cm-diameter cylinder. Because the head is noticeably heavier than the shaft, the hand becomes the pivot point while the blade end pulls downward, creating a head-heavy moment the user must control. Typical motions are shoulder- or elbow-driven chopping swings: raising the axe above the shoulder, accelerating it in a downward arc, then decelerating after impact. Wrist micro-adjustments fine-tune angle just before contact. The virtual axe behaves as a rigid body whose centre of mass is near the steel head, giving the user clear angular momentum and follow-through when swung, and a slight lag when the swing starts or reverses.

usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia.
outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip (about 3 cm Ø)
interactionDeduction: The sickle is held one-handed with a power–precision hybrid grip: palm wraps the short cylindrical handle while the thumb and fore-finger pinch closer to the blade heel for control. Interaction consists of repeated, sweeping ‘hook’ motions—elbow leads a lateral or downward arc that pulls the curved blade through crop stems. The forward-weighted blade gives the user a mild inertial tug at the start of each swing and helps carry the cut through the material. After the cut the user quickly retracts and repositions for the next stroke, feeling the blade’s momentum taper off. The object remains rigid, but its curved outline guides the path of motion, reinforcing the feeling of slicing as it drags through virtual vegetation.

inertia: Front-heavy feel from steel head (around 1 kg total).
interactionDeduction: The long handle is grasped with two power grips separated by roughly 40–60 cm: the leading (dominant) hand near the ferrule for control, the trailing hand near the butt for leverage. The user lifts the hoe head by hinging at the shoulders, then swings it downward to strike soil, finishing with a pulling motion toward the torso to scrape or break ground. The front-heavy steel head produces noticeable angular inertia; once the downward swing begins, the user experiences momentum that must be braked after impact. The tool feels rigid and transmits a solid jolt back through the shaft when the head meets resistance.

inertia: Front-heavy feel from steel head (around 1 kg total)
interactionDeduction: The user adopts a two-handed power grip on the long shaft, hands spaced 50–70 cm apart, palms facing each other. Interaction follows a thrust-and-lift pattern: (1) extend arms to spear loose hay with the tines, (2) lift by bending knees/hips and rotating wrists slightly upward, and (3) flick or roll wrists to toss the load. Because the steel tines and lower shaft add modest forward weight, initial thrusts have mild inertia, while lifting a virtual hay mass produces simulated downward force. The fork stays rigid and provides no compliance; any perceived softness comes only from the virtual hay.

interactivity: Low-friction structure underneath so the proxy would slide easily.
outline: User should perceive a pair of straight cylindrical handles (~4 cm Ø), spaced ~45 cm apart.
interactionDeduction: The user stands behind the barrow, wrapping both hands in parallel power grips around the two 4 cm-diameter wooden handles, spaced roughly shoulder-width (~45 cm). Interaction begins with a small upward tilt—pivoting around the wheel—achieved by pulling the handles up and back, shifting body weight over the single front wheel. Once balanced, the user walks forward, arms extended, pushing the barrow; the low-friction proxy makes forward translation easy to match the virtual wheel’s rolling motion. Steering is accomplished by differential pressure on the handles (slight downward torque on one side). To dump contents, the user raises the handles further, rotating the tray forward around the wheel axle, then lowers the handles back to the ground to set the barrow down. Throughout, the object feels largely rigid, with mass perception coming from the virtual load rather than handle compliance.
